deliberation: Looked for metaphor, personification, and idiom in the prophetic introduction. The key phrase is the standard formula “the word of YHWH came,” which treats the divine word as if it were a moving, arriving entity. That is a conventional but still figurative way to describe revelation.

ground: an intentional initiative from a source to a recipient
the directedness and authority of an approach
the common metaphor of communication as movement
posture: underscoring the reality and authority of the revelation
prophetic narrative framing device
rhetorical-pragmatic domain
instances.explanation: The divine message is depicted as if it were a tangible entity that comes to Jeremiah, personifying the ‘word’ and using movement as a metaphor for revelation.

deliberation: Considered whether the participles ‘doing,’ ‘forming,’ and ‘establishing’ refer to literal creation or figuratively to God’s plan/promise. In context, they describe God as crafting the announced future, using imagery of a maker shaping something. That yields a metaphor of God as artisan forming an abstract plan.

instances.english_text: GOD who is planning it, GOD who is shaping it to bring it about

vehicle: a craftsman or potter forming and establishing an object

control and skill in bringing something from idea to reality
the shared notion of crafting from conception to completion
posture: asserting God’s sovereign control and deliberateness
depicting divine planning in concrete, artisanal terms
didactic/theological domain
instances.explanation: God’s abstract plan is portrayed as something He ‘forms’ and ‘establishes’ like a crafted object, using maker imagery as a metaphor for sovereign planning.

deliberation: Examined prayer language (‘call/answer’) and the phrase ‘great and inaccessible things.’ The first treats God as a conversational partner in human terms. The second uses fortress imagery (‘בְצֻרוֹת’) for hidden knowledge. Both are distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: Call to Me, and I will answer you

the shared structure of request-and-answer interaction
posture: assuring the audience of God’s responsiveness
framing prayer in familiar interpersonal terms
pastoral/theological domain
instances.explanation: God is portrayed in human conversational terms as one who can be ‘called’ and who ‘answers,’ personifying God as a readily accessible interlocutor and using a standard idiom for prayer.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאַגִּידָה לְּךָ גְּדֹלוֹת וּבְצֻרוֹת לֹא יְדַעְתָּם

heightening Jeremiah’s dependence on revelation
didactic/theological domain
instances.explanation: The word בְצֻרוֹת (‘fortified things’) metaphorically depicts hidden knowledge as if it were a fortified city, inaccessible unless God opens it.

deliberation: Description focuses on literal houses and royal buildings torn down to strengthen defenses against siege ramps and the sword. The language is concrete and military-technical, without clear metaphor, simile, or other figures beyond normal narrative description.

Considered anthropopathic ‘anger and wrath’ and the idiom of God hiding His face. Anger/wrath is conventional anthropomorphic language; the more pointed figurative expression is ‘I hid My face from this city,’ where God’s ‘face’ stands for His favorable attention/presence.

instances.english_text: hiding My face from this city

signaling rejection and disengagement
the shared idea of removing gracious attention
posture: stressing the seriousness of the city’s sin and its consequences
casting judgment in vivid relational terms
prophetic-judgment domain
instances.explanation: God depicts His judgment as ‘hiding His face,’ a metaphorical and idiomatic way of saying He has withdrawn His favorable presence and care from the city.

deliberation: Looked for medical imagery and personification. The verse uses ‘healing’ language for the city and its people, treating corporate restoration as medical recovery and Jerusalem as a female patient.

pastoral-theological domain
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is personified as a ‘her’ who receives ‘healing,’ and the community’s restoration is metaphorically described in medical terms as cure from sickness.

deliberation: Noted two common restoration expressions: (1) ‘restore the fortunes’ (השיב שבות), an idiom for reversing calamity, and (2) ‘I will build them’ with a human collective as object, a metaphor of people as a structure God rebuilds.

instances.hebrew_text: וַהֲשִׁבֹתִי אֶת־שְׁב֣וּת יְהוּדָה וְאֵת שְׁב֣וּת יִשְׂרָאֵל

instances.explanation: The phrase ‘restore the fortunes’ is an idiomatic way of describing the reversal of exile and misery, without literally referring only to material possessions.

instances.explanation: The people are spoken of as something that can be ‘built,’ using construction imagery as a metaphor for re-establishing the nation.

deliberation: Focused on the verb ‘purify’ used with ‘sin.’ Here sin is not physical dirt, but moral guilt portrayed as impurity that can be cleansed, a well-known metaphor in biblical Hebrew.

instances.english_text: And I will purge them of all the sins that they committed

bringing into a state fit for relationship or worship
the concept of cleansing as restoration to acceptability

casting sin and forgiveness in ritual-purity terms
cultic-theological domain
instances.explanation: Sin is depicted as a kind of impurity that can be ‘purged,’ using the language of ritual and physical cleansing as a metaphor for moral and relational restoration.

deliberation: Noted: (1) Jerusalem as a ‘name’ of joy, praise, and glory—city personified and ‘name’ used for reputation (metonymy), and (2) nations ‘fearing and trembling’ because of all the good, an ironic reversal of typical fear-of-judgment language.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיְתָה לִּי לְשֵׁם שָׂשׂוֹן לִתְהִלָּה וּלְתִפְאֶרֶת לְכֹל גּוֹיֵי הָאָרֶץ

personifying the city as a celebrated figure before nations
rhetorical-praise domain
instances.explanation: Jerusalem (a ‘she’) is said to become ‘a name’ of joy, praise, and glory. The ‘name’ stands metonymically for reputation, and the city is personified as a bearer of honor among the nations.

instances.hebrew_text: וּפָחֲדוּ וְרָגְזוּ עַל כׇּל־הַטּוֹבָה וְעַל כׇּל־הַשָּׁלוֹם אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי עֹשֶׂה לָהּ

subverting usual judgment-language to describe blessing
rhetorical/ironic domain
instances.explanation: Language typically used for terror at judgment (‘fear’ and ‘tremble’) is ironically applied to the nations’ response to God’s overwhelming goodness, creating a striking rhetorical reversal.

deliberation: The verse describes desolation in straightforward terms: the place is ‘ruined, without humans and without animals.’ Given the historical situation, this can be taken literally rather than as hyperbole or figure. No distinct figurative expressions stand out beyond normal descriptive language.

Observed two figurative elements: (1) the repeated ‘voice of joy… voice of bridegroom and bride’ functions as a synecdochic/metonymic shorthand for full communal flourishing, and (2) ‘restore the fortunes of the land’ is again an idiom, with ‘land’ standing metonymically for its people.

instances.hebrew_text: ק֣וֹל שָׂשׂוֹן וְקוֹל שִׂמְחָה קוֹל חָתָן וְקוֹל כַּלָּה

part representing the whole range of social vitality
posture: evoking a vivid picture of restored community life
using emblematic sounds as shorthand for comprehensive joy
rhetorical-imagistic domain
instances.explanation: The ‘voice of joy’ and of ‘bridegroom and bride’ is more than literal sound; it functions as synecdoche/metonymy, where these characteristic noises stand for the return of full communal and familial flourishing.

instances.english_text: For I will restore the fortunes of the land as of old

vehicle: restoration of what had been removed

undoing the state of ruin
conceptualizing restoration as retrieval of former wellbeing
posture: framing restoration in conventional exilic idiom
assuring a full return to earlier stability
pastoral/prophetic domain
instances.explanation: ‘Restore the fortunes of the land’ is an idiomatic formula for comprehensive restoration, with ‘land’ metonymically representing the community dwelling in it.

deliberation: This verse speaks of a ruined place again becoming ‘a pasture for shepherds, where they can rest their flocks.’ In context it most naturally describes literal pastoral use returning to the region and does not obviously function as a metaphor for something else, so I treat it as non-figurative here.

Describes sheep passing under the hands of one who counts them in specific geographical regions. This reflects literal shepherding practice and geographic detail; no clear metaphor or symbolic transfer to another domain is explicitly marked in the verse.

Looked at ‘days are coming’ (a temporal idiom) and ‘I will raise up/establish the good word.’ The idiom for time is fairly literal within prophetic style, but ‘establish the good word’ conceptualizes a promise as something that can be raised up or set in place, which is metaphorical.

instances.english_text: when I will fulfill [lit. raise up/establish] the good promise

ground: bringing something from intent/plan into visible reality
making something stand firm and operative
the notion of actualizing a prior commitment
posture: emphasizing the solidity and reliability of God’s promise
casting fulfillment as a concrete, structural act
didactic/theological domain
instances.explanation: The ‘good word’ (promise) is treated as something God can ‘raise up’ or ‘establish,’ using construction imagery as a metaphor for bringing a promise into reality.

deliberation: The key figure is ‘a righteous Branch’ caused to sprout for David, where a royal descendant is conceptualized as plant growth. This is a clear and central metaphor in prophetic literature.

instances.english_text: I will raise up a true branch of David’s line

organic, God-given growth and vitality
the continuity and renewal of a lineage
posture: depicting the coming ruler as God-nurtured new growth
linking justice with fresh, living vitality
prophetic-messianic domain
instances.explanation: The future Davidic king is metaphorically portrayed as a ‘branch’ that God causes to sprout from David, using plant imagery to convey continuity, life, and righteousness.

deliberation: Saw (1) personification of Jerusalem as a woman who ‘dwells securely,’ and (2) the naming ‘YHWH our Righteousness/Vindicator,’ where YHWH is characterized metaphorically as the people’s righteousness or vindication.

instances.english_text: and Jerusalem shall dwell secure

experience of calm, undisturbed existence
the notion of being at home and unafraid
posture: comforting the audience with a picture of stable security
portraying the city as a person living at ease
pastoral/prophetic domain
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is personified as one who ‘dwells’ in safety, using the imagery of an individual living securely at home to describe corporate security.

instances.english_text: GOD is our Vindicator [lit. YHWH our righteousness]

status of the community before God

identification of the community’s righteousness with God Himself
the concept of sheltering under someone else’s just status
posture: affirming that the city’s justice and vindication derive from YHWH
encapsulating theology in a symbolic name
confessional-theological domain
instances.explanation: The name ‘YHWH our Righteousness’ metaphorically attributes to God the role of being the people’s righteousness or vindicator, not just the one who commands righteousness.

deliberation: Considered whether the ‘throne’ is figurative. While kings literally sat on a throne, ‘sit on the throne of the house of Israel’ also functions metonymically for exercising kingship/rule, with the throne symbolizing the institution of royal authority.

instances.english_text: one of David’s line who sit upon the throne of the House of Israel

the association of a seat with the power it confers

evoking the symbol of kingship to assure political stability
prophetic-promise domain
instances.explanation: The ‘throne’ stands metonymically for the institution and authority of kingship; to have someone ‘sit on the throne’ is to say that Davidic royal rule continues.

deliberation: The verse speaks of levitical priests presenting offerings and sacrifices ‘before Me.’ Given the cultic context, this language straightforwardly describes actual priestly service and presence; no distinct metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond standard cultic terminology is evident.
Once again uses the prophetic formula ‘the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah,’ repeating the figurative depiction of revelation as an arriving ‘word.’

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to Jeremiah
target: the new instance of divine revelation to Jeremiah
vehicle: a ‘word’ that arrives like a person or object
ground: a discrete, intentional approach from speaker to recipient
the idea of authoritative initiative from God
the communication-as-movement conceptual mapping
posture: marking a fresh divine message with authoritative framing
linking Jeremiah’s speech tightly to God’s initiative
rhetorical-pragmatic domain
instances.explanation: As in other prophetic texts, the divine message is personified and depicted as ‘coming’ to Jeremiah, figuratively portraying revelation as a moving, arriving entity.

deliberation: Detected two intertwined figures: (1) day and night as covenant partners with God—personification/metaphor for the fixed created order—and (2) ‘day and night’ together as a merism for the totality of time.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־תָּפֵרוּ אֶת־בְּרִיתִי הַיּוֹם וְאֶת־בְּרִיתִי הַלָּיְלָה וּלְבִלְתִּי הֱיוֹת יומם־וָלַיְלָה בְּעִתָּם
instances.english_text: If you could break My covenant with the day and My covenant with the night, so that day and night should not come at their proper time

ground: both the cosmic order and God’s promise are fixed and dependable
day and night together representing the totality and constancy of time (merism)
the impossibility of disrupting either order or covenant
posture: arguing from the impossibility of breaking natural order to the impossibility of breaking God’s covenant
heightening assurance through vivid cosmic personification
rhetorical-theological domain
instances.explanation: Day and night are personified as covenant partners with God, and the pair ‘day and night’ functions as a merism for all time. Breaking such a ‘covenant’ is imagined to be as impossible as disrupting the basic rhythms of creation.

deliberation: Parallel to v.17, this verse mentions a son ‘reigning on his throne.’ The key figurative element is again the ‘throne’ as symbol/metonym for the institution and exercise of kingship, rather than merely the furniture.

instances.english_text: so that he would not have a descendant reigning upon his throne

the seat stands for the office
the close association of symbol and institution
posture: emphasizing the permanence of royal office rather than the object itself
linking God’s covenant to the visible symbol of authority
prophetic-promise domain
instances.explanation: The ‘throne’ is used metonymically for the dynastic office and exercise of kingship; reigning ‘on his throne’ means exercising Davidic royal authority.

deliberation: Identified the explicit comparison ‘like the host of heaven… and the sand of the sea,’ echoing the Abrahamic promises. This is a simile that uses hyperbolic imagery to convey innumerability.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יִסָּפֵר צְבָא הַשָּׁמַיִם וְלֹא יִמַּד חוֹל הַיָּם כֵּן אַרְבֶּה אֶת־זֶרַע דָּוִד עַבְדִּי וְאֶת־הַלְוִיִּם מְשָׁרְתֵי אֹתִי

assuring abundance beyond ordinary enumeration
rhetorical-promise domain
instances.explanation: Using a traditional simile, God compares the multiplication of David’s and the Levites’ offspring to the uncountable stars and sand—a hyperbolic image expressing vast, essentially innumerable growth.

deliberation: Again uses the formula ‘the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah,’ which continues the established figurative depiction of revelation as an arriving “word.”

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to Jeremiah

ground: initiative and directedness of communication

the metaphorical mapping of messages as moving objects
posture: reinforcing the authority and origin of Jeremiah’s message
signaling a new oracle in a conventional way
rhetorical-pragmatic domain
instances.explanation: The divine message is again personified and pictured as ‘coming’ to Jeremiah, using movement imagery to portray revelation.

deliberation: Considered whether ‘two families’ and ‘nation’ are purely literal. The phrase ‘two families that YHWH chose’ refers to the two covenant peoples/kingdoms (Israel and Judah) under dynastic heads, making ‘families’ a metonymic/synecdochic label for whole national entities.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁתֵּי הַמִּשְׁפָּחוֹת אֲשֶׁר בָּחַר יְהוָה בָּהֶם

reflecting popular speech that reduces nations to their leading ‘families’
rhetorical-social domain
instances.explanation: The ‘two families’ function metonymically/synecdochically for the two covenant nations/kingdoms descended from them, reducing entire peoples to their representative houses.

deliberation: Parallels v.20: ‘My covenant with day and night’ and ‘the laws of heaven and earth.’ These expressions personify cosmic order as if God had made a covenant with time itself, and present the fixed structures of creation as covenantal ‘statutes.’

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־לֹא בְרִיתִי יוֹמָם וָלַיְלָה חֻקּוֹת שָׁמַיִם וָאָרֶץ לֹא־שָׂמְתִּי

the idea of binding order underlying creation
posture: arguing from the unshakable cosmic order to the unshakable covenant
heightening assurance through legal and cosmic imagery
rhetorical-theological domain
instances.explanation: Day and night, heaven and earth, are personified and treated as covenant partners and statute-bearers, so that cosmic regularity becomes a metaphor and guarantee for God’s steadfast covenant.

deliberation: Identified the now-familiar idiom ‘restore their fortunes’ as the key figurative expression, promising reversal of exile and misery, rather than merely financial gain.

pastoral/prophetic domain
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘restore their fortunes’ encapsulates the idea of reversing exile and suffering, promising a full return to favor rather than merely financial restitution.
